conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-emergency notifications during work hours, but User Story B wants caregivers to get notifications anytime. This creates opposite instructions about sending notifications under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-emergency notifications during my work hours, so I can focus on patient care without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Implemented a context-aware notification policy that blocks non-emergency alerts during caregiver work hours but allows emergency notifications anytime to ensure quick help.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-emergency notifications during my work hours, so I can focus on care without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get emergency notifications anytime, so they can help me quickly.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency alerts during work hours, while User Story B wants caregivers to get notifications anytime. These two requirements contradict because one forbids sending notifications at certain times, and the other demands notifications anytime.
userStoryASummary: As a busy nurse, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency alerts during work hours so I can focus on urgent patient care without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Apply a context-aware policy that allows blocking non-emergency alerts during work hours but ensures caregivers receive emergency notifications anytime.
newUserStoryASummary: As a busy nurse, I want ALFRED to block non-emergency alerts during work hours so I can focus on urgent care without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime for emergencies to get help quickly.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-clinical notifications during work, while User Story B wants caregivers to get notifications anytime to help quickly. These are opposite instructions for the same event of sending notifications.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block all non-clinical notifications during work to avoid distractions and focus only on patient health data.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are adjusted to include context-aware notification rules, allowing caregivers to receive critical clinical notifications anytime while blocking non-clinical notifications during work hours to reduce distractions.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block non-clinical notifications during work hours to focus on patient health data without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to receive clinical notifications anytime to get quick help when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to block non-urgent notifications during caregiver work hours (forbid operation), while User Story B wants caregivers to get notifications anytime (start operation). These two impose opposite instructions on notification delivery at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-urgent notifications during my work hours so I can focus without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow non-urgent notifications to be blocked only during caregiver work hours, while urgent notifications are always sent to caregivers for timely help.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-urgent notifications during my work hours so I can focus without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get urgent notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to block all notifications during caregiver work hours, while User Story B requires notifications to be sent anytime to caregivers for quick help. These are opposite instructions for the same event of sending notifications.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all notifications during my work hours, so I can focus only on urgent patient care without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Notifications to caregivers are blocked during non-urgent times within work hours but allowed anytime for urgent help, balancing focus and quick response.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-urgent notifications during my work hours, so I can focus on patient care without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime for urgent help, so I receive quick assistance when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all notifications during work hours, while User Story B wants caregivers to get notifications anytime. These are opposite instructions for the same event (notifications during work hours).
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block all notifications during work hours to avoid distractions and focus on patient care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: Update User Story A to allow caregiver notifications during emergencies or urgent health events while keeping User Story B unchanged. This balances caregiver focus during work hours and quick help for the older adult.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block non-urgent notifications during work hours to avoid distractions but allow urgent alerts for quick response.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-medical notifications during caregiver shifts to avoid distractions, while User Story B wants caregivers to receive notifications anytime to help quickly. These two impose opposite instructions on notification delivery at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-medical notifications during my work shifts to avoid distractions and focus only on clinical data.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Introduce a context-aware notification policy that blocks non-medical notifications during caregiver shifts except for urgent alerts, ensuring caregivers get important notifications without distractions.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-urgent notifications during my work shifts to focus on clinical data without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to receive urgent notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants caregivers to control and limit notifications to avoid overload, while User Story B wants caregivers to get notifications anytime to help quickly. These are opposite instructions for when notifications should be sent.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications for each client myself, so I can avoid overload and stay ready to help.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: A context-aware notification control is introduced to balance timely notifications and avoid overload by allowing caregivers to set notification preferences with emergency overrides.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manage notification settings for each client, so I can avoid overload while staying informed.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get important notifications quickly, so they can help me when needed.

conflictDescription: The informal caregiver wants to choose and limit notifications to reduce alerts, while the older adult wants caregivers to receive notifications anytime for quick help. These are conflicting expectations about how often notifications should be sent.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose which notifications I get from ALFRED for each client, so I can focus and not get too many alerts.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Notifications frequency is made configurable so caregivers can limit alerts while ensuring urgent notifications are sent immediately for quick help.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to set notification preferences for each client, so I can reduce unnecessary alerts and focus on important ones.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to receive urgent notifications immediately, so they can help me quickly when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to manage and delay non-emergency notifications outside work hours, while User Story B expects caregivers to get notifications anytime for quick help. These oppose each other on when notifications should be sent.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see and manage non-emergency notifications outside work hours, so I can respond clearly and well.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: We introduce a context-aware notification policy that delays non-urgent notifications outside work hours but allows urgent notifications anytime for quick help. Both user stories are updated to reflect this balance.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manage non-emergency notifications outside work hours, so I can respond clearly and well when I am available.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get urgent notifications anytime, so they can help me quickly when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants non-urgent notifications sent outside work hours only, while User Story B wants caregivers to get all notifications anytime. These trigger conditions for sending notifications differ and are mutually exclusive.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all urgent ALFRED notifications anytime and non-urgent ones outside work hours to stay ready to help.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Merge notification timing conditions to allow urgent notifications anytime and non-urgent notifications with caregiver preference for timing, balancing both needs.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent notifications anytime and non-urgent ones based on my preferred hours to help effectively.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get urgent notifications anytime and non-urgent ones during suitable times to get timely help.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants caregivers to control and possibly limit notifications to avoid overload, while User Story B wants caregivers to receive notifications anytime for quick help. These are opposite expectations on when notifications should be sent.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications for each client myself, so I can manage my attention and avoid feeling overloaded.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Notifications are controlled by caregivers with priority for urgent alerts, balancing overload and quick help using context-aware rules.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notification settings, so I can manage my attention and avoid overload.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want urgent notifications sent immediately, so caregivers can help me quickly when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to limit or control when notifications are sent to avoid overload, while User Story B wants notifications sent anytime without delay for quick help. These are opposite expectations about notification timing.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver managing many clients, I want to choose which notifications to see and when, so I do not miss important alerts or feel too busy.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get notifications anytime so they can help me quickly.
resolutionDescription: Apply a context-aware policy that allows caregivers to receive urgent notifications immediately, while letting informal caregivers configure notification preferences to avoid overload.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose important notifications and their timing, so I avoid feeling too busy but stay informed.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get urgent notifications right away, so they can help me quickly when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to limit and control data logging to protect privacy, but User Story B wants to share all health data freely with the caregiver, which means full logging. These two are opposite instructions about data recording and sharing.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to select what data is logged and limit automatic recording, so that privacy is protected.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person I want to share all my health data freely with my informal caregiver so I feel fully supported and cared for.
resolutionDescription: We balance privacy and support by allowing users to control which health data is shared, enabling selective logging and sharing based on consent.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control which health data is logged, so that the older adult's privacy is protected.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share selected health data with my informal caregiver, so I feel supported while keeping some privacy.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to limit and control what data is logged, forbidding automatic recording of some data. User Story B wants all health data to be shared freely with medical staff, expecting full automatic data sharing. These are opposite expectations about data sharing behavior.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to select what data is logged and limit automatic recording, so that privacy is protected.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want all my health data to be shared freely with medical staff to get the best care possible.
resolutionDescription: Apply a context-aware policy to allow caregivers to select data sharing preferences, while enabling automatic sharing of critical health data with medical staff for care.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control which health data is shared automatically, so that privacy is protected but important data is shared.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want critical health data shared with medical staff automatically, so that I get the best possible care.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires manual control to restrict sharing client data, while User Story B wants to share all health data freely with the caregiver. These are opposite instructions about data sharing for the same event of data access.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually control sharing of client data within privacy settings, so I can protect their privacy.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person I want to share all my health data freely with my informal caregiver so I feel fully supported and cared for.
resolutionDescription: Apply a contextual policy layer where data sharing is allowed by default but includes manual controls to restrict sharing when needed, balancing privacy and support.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want manual control to restrict client data sharing, so I can protect their privacy when needed.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share most health data freely with my informal caregiver, so I feel supported while keeping some privacy control.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to manually control and limit data sharing to protect privacy, while User Story B wants all health data to be shared freely with medical staff. These are opposite expectations on data sharing behavior that cannot both happen at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually control sharing of client data within privacy settings, so I can protect their privacy.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want all my health data to be shared freely with medical staff to get the best care possible.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow controlled sharing based on user consent, balancing privacy control and data availability for care.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control data sharing with consent, so I protect privacy and support care.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want my health data shared with medical staff when I agree, to get good care.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to send medication reminders automatically and adjust their strength, while User Story B requires the older adult to freely decide when and how to set reminders, implying ALFRED should not enforce reminders without user consent. These are opposite expectations about the same reminder operation.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength, so patients take medicine on time without feeling stressed.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to freely decide when and how to set reminders for my health appointments, so I feel in control and not pressured.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength only with the user's consent, balancing caregiver needs and user control.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength with user consent, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to decide when and how to set medication reminders, so I feel in control and supported by ALFRED.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to send medication reminders automatically without restrictions, while User Story B wants reminders only when the older adult allows. These are opposite instructions about sending reminders automatically.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength, so patients take medicine on time without feeling stressed.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to give me reminders automatically only when I allow, so I get help without losing control.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow reminders that adjust in strength and are sent automatically but only when the older adult consents, balancing caregiver needs and user control.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to give me reminders automatically when I allow, so I get help without losing control.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires forcing hard exercises without allowing difficulty changes, while User Story B wants frequent reminders to do hard exercises but implies user choice. These are opposite expectations about user control during exercise.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often to do hard exercises and health checks, so I can stay motivated and improve my health.
resolutionDescription: The first story is updated to allow some adaptability in exercise difficulty while maintaining clinical goals. The second story is updated to include reminders for exercises with user choice on difficulty, balancing motivation and control.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to guide patients to do challenging exercises with limited difficulty changes, so I can meet clinical goals safely.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often to do exercises and health checks, allowing me to adjust difficulty to stay motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to force hard exercises without allowing difficulty change, while User Story B wants to suggest rest after hard exercises to allow recovery. Both impose opposite instructions related to handling hard exercises at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult I want ALFRED to suggest short rest times after hard exercises so I can recover but still feel challenged.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow hard exercises with controlled difficulty and include suggested rest periods for recovery to balance clinical goals and user well-being.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set hard exercises with fixed difficulty, so clinical goals are met safely.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to suggest short rest times after hard exercises, so I can recover and stay challenged.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires forcing patients to do hard exercises without changing difficulty, while User Story B requires allowing older adults to choose their exercise time freely. The conflict is about control over exercise settings and scheduling, with one story forcing a fixed difficulty and the other allowing user choice, which cannot be satisfied together at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to choose my exercise time freely so I feel in control and motivated.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: The caregiver's story is updated to allow varying exercise difficulty within clinical limits, while the older adult's story remains to keep freedom over exercise time, resolving the control conflict.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise difficulty within safe limits, so patients meet clinical goals while allowing some flexibility.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to choose my exercise time freely so I feel in control and motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires forcing patients to do hard exercises without allowing changes in difficulty, while User Story B requires allowing older adults to choose when to start exercises, which implies control over exercise timing and potentially difficulty. These two impose opposite instructions on control over exercise execution.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to choose when to start exercises so I can keep control and stay motivated.
resolutionDescription: Modify both stories to allow caregiver control over exercise difficulty while giving older adults choice on exercise timing, balancing clinical goals and user motivation.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise difficulty for patients to meet clinical goals, so exercises are effective.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to choose when to start exercises to keep control and stay motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants the system to force hard exercises without allowing changes, while User Story B wants the user to freely decide when to set reminders, meaning to control timing and pressure. These impose opposite expectations on system control over reminders and activities.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to freely decide when and how to set reminders for my health appointments, so I feel in control and not pressured.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: The caregiver's user story is updated to allow some flexibility in exercise difficulty under specific conditions, while the older adult's story keeps the control over reminders, balancing clinical goals and user autonomy.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise difficulty levels for patients with limited ability to adjust them, so clinical goals can mostly be met while respecting user preferences.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to freely decide when and how to set reminders for my health appointments, so I feel in control and not pressured.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to force hard exercises without letting patients change difficulty, but User Story B wants to maintain independence with ALFRED reminders, implying freedom to manage prompts and actions. These opposing instructions create a conflict on control over exercise difficulty.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often and keep me fully informed to support my health without limiting my independence.
resolutionDescription: We adapt User Story A to allow fixed exercise difficulty for specific clinical sessions and update User Story B to keep reminders but allow some guidance control, balancing clinical goals with user independence.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set fixed exercise difficulty during clinical sessions, so patients follow treatment goals closely.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often and support my health with gentle guidance, so I keep my independence.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires forcing hard exercises without allowing changes, while User Story B requires reminders only when the older adult allows. These impose opposite system behaviors on when to start exercise reminders and actions.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to give me reminders automatically only when I allow, so I get help without losing control.
resolutionDescription: Adjust both stories to allow caregiver-set exercise goals with reminders sent only when the older adult consents, balancing clinical needs and user control.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise goals to meet clinical needs, so patients get proper care.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to send exercise reminders only when I allow, so I keep control over my activities.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants to set exercise goals to meet clinical needs, which may include controlling difficulty, while the older adult wants surprise hard exercise challenges. These are opposite expectations about exercise difficulty and control, causing a conflict in system behavior.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise goals to meet clinical needs, so patients get proper care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to give me surprise hard exercise challenges, so I can keep motivated and get stronger.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow controlled exercise difficulty with occasional surprise challenges, balancing clinical safety and motivation.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise goals with adjustable difficulty, so patients get safe and effective care.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to offer occasional surprise exercise challenges, so I stay motivated and improve strength.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants reminders that adjust in strength and happen only when allowed to avoid stress, while User Story B wants frequent reminders with gentle guidance. These differ in how often and how strongly reminders are given, creating a conflict in reminder frequency and intensity.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often and support my health with gentle guidance, so I keep my independence.
resolutionDescription: The conflict about reminder frequency and strength is resolved by setting reminders to be adjustable in strength and frequency, respecting user stress and independence preferences.
newUserStoryASummary: As a caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and timing, so patients take medicine without stress.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me gently and regularly, so I keep my health and independence.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires video calls only during scheduled times at the hospital, while User Story B wants video calls for exercise challenges anywhere. These are conflicting triggering conditions for video calls.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to receive video call requests only during scheduled times at my hospital, so I can focus on care and keep clear work boundaries.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enjoy video calls for exercise challenges anywhere, so I stay motivated and active.
resolutionDescription: We adjust both stories to define clear, complementary conditions: scheduled video calls for caregivers and flexible video calls for exercise challenges outside scheduled care times.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to receive video call requests only during scheduled hospital times, so I can focus on care and keep clear work boundaries.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enjoy video calls for exercise challenges anytime outside scheduled care, so I stay motivated and active.
